Issues.Title: Selected dropdown button in `PropertyGrid` entry has visual artifacts on Windows 11
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version:
3.0, 3.1, 5.0, 6.0, 7.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes, at 4.7.2 and 4.8, but in a bit different manner (see the screenshot below)

**Problem description:**
When the drop down button is selected with the mouse cursor, there're some visual artifacts on this button:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145568114-c12b791c-63f6-43cd-9ca0-5bb52408a55b.png)

This button at .NET Framework 4.7.2/4.8 at Windows 11 also have some kinds of disruption:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145568339-13555736-7ca2-4225-b393-d134617572ce.png)

General `ComboBox` control and `ComboBox` in the `DataGridViewComboBoxColumn` look fine at Windows 11 though:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145567247-ff4053d4-131c-4c07-8e44-649d6fe515b9.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145567416-59fc8c7a-1f73-47a8-971e-5b415ad3a427.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The button should look the same way it looks at Windows 10:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145568713-dec53d71-1c85-41d5-b348-4846e69d82da.png)

**Minimal repro:**
- Build and run the project from the attached zip file at Windows 11
- Click on PropertyGrid entry named `Flag` to make the ComboBox button visible
- Point the mouse cursor at the DropDown opening button (with down arrow)
![button](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145570544-e9ec47ed-cd8f-431c-84d2-833f6d514c7b.gif)

[TestPgCore.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/7692500/TestPgCore.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Selected dropdown button in `PropertyGrid` entry has visual artifacts on Windows 11" (#6326)

Issues.Title: Enable template localization on dotnet CLI
Issues.Body:
## Background:
 Template engine (`dotnet new`) added support for template localizations in .NET 6.0. This new system replaces the old way of localizing templates that only worked on Visual Studio and works on both .NET CLI as well as VS.

This PR introduces changes to switch to the new template localization system.

## Summary of the changes
- Adds `<UsingToolTemplateLocalizer>true</>` to projects containing templates.
- Adds necessary `id` fields into `template.json` files to allow localizing certain fields (specifically, post actions).
- Generates localization files to be translated by loc team


## What to expect after merging
Every time there is a change to one of the templates:
- The dev making the change should build (at the very least) the modified template project. This will update the loc files on the local working copy,
- Push the loc files together with the template modifications. Review & merge.
- OneLocBuild integration will automatically pick up the changes and will send them for translation.
- You will receive a PR containing the translated template loc files when they are ready. Review & merge.


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/6319)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Enable template localization on dotnet CLI" (#6319)

Issues.Title: Move the rest of duplicate logic of `GetPropertyValue` to base class
Issues.Body:
We should investigate and refactor the following cases by moving them to the `GetPropertyValue` method of the base class from the children classes:
- `IsInvokePatternAvailablePropertyId` (needs special attention because the `AccessibleObject` class uses a large switch inside the `IsInvokePatternAvailable` property for checking `IsInvokePatternAvailablePropertyId` property, we need to be sure that logic will be still consistent with the children classes)
- `LegacyIAccessibleStatePropertyId`
- `LegacyIAccessibleValuePropertyId`
- `LegacyIAccessibleRolePropertyId`
- `IsSelectionItemPatternAvailablePropertyId` at the `ComboBoxItemAccessibleObject` class and similar scenarios (check consistency with the `IsPatternSupported` method of the child class)
- `IsLegacyIAccessiblePatternAvailablePropertyId` at the `DropDownButtonAccessibleObject` class and similar scenarios
- `IsTablePatternAvailablePropertyId` at the `PropertyGridViewAccessibleObject` class and similar scenarios
- `IsGridPatternAvailablePropertyId` at the `PropertyGridViewAccessibleObject` class and similar scenarios
- `IsExpandCollapsePatternAvailablePropertyId` at the `ToolStripItemAccessibleObject` class and similar scenarios

Original issue:
- #5494

Original PR: 
- #5745

Related issues:
- #6103
- #6236
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Move the rest of duplicate logic of `GetPropertyValue` to base class" (#6324)

Issues.Title: The ToolStripButton borders have low color contrast ratio in high contrast mode on win11 OS
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* OS Version: Win11
* .NET Core Version: 
.NET Core SDK: 7.0.0-alpha.1.21568.2

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

* More info: 
1. There is a known issue: [6220](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/6220) about this on Win10 OS
2. This issue is reproducing when high contrast is Aquatic/Dusk/Night sky
3. This issue doesn't repro when high contrast is Desert

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a Winforms application with ToolStrip added
2. Set ToolStrip.RenderMode as **System**
3. Add a toolStripbutton for ToolStrip and set its Enabled=True, Checked=True
4. Enable high contrast mode
4. Run the app and launch Accessibility Insights for Windows tool

**Actual behavior:**
High contrast: Aquatic
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/145318964-e54e5b2e-cf7e-44dd-bcaa-caf1084fd844.png)

High contrast: Dusk
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/145318978-415dabee-2a01-49ca-84f3-a73b67198daa.png)

High contrast: Night sky
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/145318992-b3ad18b4-c65e-4757-a431-2a2d045b7aa3.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The color contrast ratio should greater than 3:1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The ToolStripButton borders have low color contrast ratio in high contrast mode on win11 OS" (#6322)

Issues.Title: Accessibility: Inspect: The LegacyIAccessible.DefaultAction property should not be empty for Collapsed/Expanded DateTimePicker
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net 7.0 SDK build: 7.0.100-alpha.1.21568.2

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application
2. Add a DateTimePicker control to form designer
3. Build and run application, then use Inspect to detect it when DateTimePicker is collapsed and expanded, pay attention to the LegacyIAccessible.DefaultAction property

**Actual behavior:**
LegacyIAccessible.DefaultAction property is empty when DateTimePicker is collapsed or expanded
Collapse:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/145175364-c96c55d5-d7ec-4f48-9f89-61ba9f3900b2.png)
Expand:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/145175531-4ee7aa87-f838-4270-bade-15cc457c3934.png)
**Expected behavior:**
LegacyIAccessible.DefaultAction property should be same as ComboBox control when it is collapsed or expanded
ComboBox is collapsed:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/145176345-f3341db1-b869-42c4-bc3b-4b906dc75173.png)
ComboBox is expanded:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/145176483-798c7445-b5b8-4292-91b7-b09ea296c9ab.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Accessibility: Inspect: The LegacyIAccessible.DefaultAction property should not be empty for Collapsed/Expanded DateTimePicker" (#6317)

Issues.Title: Fixing dotline rectangle for focused `Button` with `Standard` FlatStyle
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4538

## Proposed changes

- After zooming in it's visible that dotline rectangle for the focused `Button` with FlatStyle set to `Standard` is still there, but it intersects with the blue border:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145019536-bad5bd4a-5b7f-490c-9ab5-ef73f01ca1d8.png)
- At .Net 5.0 there's no such intersection:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145019583-5b987914-f5cb-443e-bc1b-c9a29543291a.png)
- This intersection happens because the focus rectangle is inflated for one pixel, and to fix this issue we should add a condition on this inflating to exclude the `Standard` FlatStyle case

## Before the fix
- ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145019797-713ff86e-9bf3-46de-bf17-01c5e5658ef6.png)
- ![buttonsBeforeFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145020580-a20358f8-562b-4991-9387-7ed5dddb1e1c.gif)


## After the fix
- ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145019827-55050b73-15c6-4b02-9b88-36b8bcf0a4ea.png)
- ![buttonsAfterFix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/87859299/145020609-0ff118b3-ea04-4485-a06f-6f51832e009e.gif)

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing (see the `After the fix` section)
- CTI team

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19043.1348]
.NET SDK 7.0.100-alpha.1.21606.1

Issues.Title: Improving accessible object for label edit in ListView
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4810. Implements an accessible object for label edit control in ListView. This object now is the last child of the ListView (the same behavior as in the Windows Explorer). The object now also has a non-empty name according to its value (Windows Explorer behavior). The original object wasn't producing automation events related to the text, it was done by the UIAutomationCore proxy -- this was also implemented along with the text pattern support for the new accessible object, so the Narrator announces its text correctly.


## Proposed changes

- Implemented native window wrapper and accessible object for label edit control in ListView
- Implemented text pattern provider for label edit control (and added triggering automation events about label edit text)
- Made label edit accessible object be the last child of ListView (Windows Explorer behavior)
- Made label edit name value set according to its text value (Windows Explorer behavior)

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Narrator now announces the name of the label edit control

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5282741/145061988-b1036a93-9ca3-45e9-8c04-a9e20912431e.png)


### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5282741/145062071-9e26f1a3-d4e4-4c6b-a992-1519c45a6553.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual (using inspect and Narrator tools to verify hierarchy and text pattern)
- Unit-tests (not currently presented)
- CTI (planned)


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19044.1348]
- .NET 7.0.0-alpha.1.21602.1


<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->

Issues.Title: The accessibility rectangle is drawn incorrectly for a dynamically added ListViewGroup.
Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version: 
- 7.0.0-alpha.1.21576.4

Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
- No (from .NET Core 6.0)

**Repro steps:**
1. Create a `Form` with a `ListView` and a `Button`.
2. Add an event for a `Button` to add multiple `ListViewGroups` with `ListViewItems`.
3. Run the application
4. Add `ListViewGroups` using the `Button`
5. Get accessibility rectangle for `ListViewGroup` (using `Inspect`)

**Actual behavior:**
The rectangle for the `ListViewGroup` is displayed incorrectly.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/145034311-3a51a6e5-899a-49f0-8997-4f72c76e1986.png)


**Expected behavior:**
The rectangle for the `ListViewGroup` should be displayed correctly.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/145034658-f212aaf3-f2dd-4efb-8ee2-ac19d0b15d57.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The accessibility rectangle is drawn incorrectly for a dynamically added ListViewGroup." (#6306)

Issues.Title: "ComboBox.SelectedItem" property throws an exception if the selected item was removed and Handle is not created
Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version: 
- 7.0.0-alpha.1.21576.4

Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
- No (the issue is not reproduced only in .NET Core 3.0, because when setting the `SelectedItem` property, we forcibly create a `Handle`)

**Repro steps:**
1. Create `ComboBox` and add some `Items`.
2. Set the last `Item` as the `SelectedItem`.
3. Remove last `Item`
4. Try to get the `SelectedItem` property

**Actual behavior:**
User sees an `ArgumentOutOfRangeException`.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/145021646-12781650-1d3a-46b9-8b50-0f0b01903854.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The user should not see the exception.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue ""ComboBox.SelectedItem" property throws an exception if the selected item was removed and Handle is not created" (#6304)
